hypotheses: Education and individual time preferences significantly affect asymptomatic disease detection and management.
The effects of education and time preferences on disease detection differ between healthy and unhealthy individuals.
claim.statement: We study the roles of education and individual time preferences in asymptomatic disease detection and management. Using discrete choice models on a sample of 4209 hypertensive Indonesian adults surveyed between November 2007 and April 2008, we find that both education and individual time preferences play important roles.

data.source: Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS), fourth wave
data.wave_or_subset: Fourth wave, surveyed between November 2007 and April 2008
data.access_details: The IFLS is a publicly available data set and has received IRB approval both at RAND and in Indonesia.
data.notes: Survey includes a module on elicited risk and time preference parameters; measurement errors are discussed regarding income data.

method.description: The study uses discrete choice models to analyze the effect of education and time preferences on hypertension under-diagnosis and disease management. The analysis distinguishes effects between respondents in good and poor health.
steps: Collect data from the IFLS 2007-2008 survey wave.
Identify hypertensive individuals and classify them into under-diagnosed and previously diagnosed groups.
Elicit time and risk preferences using hypothetical lottery questions.
Estimate probit regression models to assess determinants of disease detection and management, focusing on education and time preferences.
method.outcome_variable: Probability of being under-diagnosed with hypertension; Probability of engaging in good disease management
method.independent_variables: Years of education, time preference, risk preference, distance to health center, household per capita expenditures, sex

results.summary: Education affects disease management more for individuals in poor health. Time preference affects disease detection significantly in healthy individuals, but not in the unhealthy. Economic resources play a crucial role in both detection and management.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Impact of education on disease management

metadata.original_paper_title: Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection
metadata.original_paper_data: The IFLS dataset is publicly available but the specific access link is not stated.
